review.title: General-Purpose MCMC Inference over Relational Structures
review.abstract: Tasks such as record linkage and multi-target tracking, which involve reconstructing the set of objects that underlie some observed data, are particularly challenging for probabilistic inference. Recent work has achieved efficient and accurate inference on such problems using Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) techniques with customized proposal distributions. Currently, implementing such a system requires coding MCMC state representations and acceptance probability calculations that are specific to a particular application. An alternative approach, which we pursue in this paper, is to use a general-purpose probabilistic modeling language (such as BLOG) and a generic Metropolis-Hastings MCMC algorithm that supports user-supplied proposal distributions. Our algorithm gains flexibility by using MCMC states that are only partial descriptions of possible worlds; we provide conditions under which MCMC over partial worlds yields correct answers to queries. We also show how to use a context-specific Bayes net to identify the factors in the acceptance probability that need to be computed for a given proposed move. Experimental results on a citation matching task show that our general-purpose MCMC engine compares favorably with an application-specific system.

sections.text: Tasks such as record-linking and multi-goal tracking, which involve reconstructing the group of objects underlying some observed data, present a particular challenge for likely conclusions. Recent work has reached efficient and precise conclusions on such problems using techniques from the Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) with tailor-made offer distributions. Currently, the implementation of such a system requires the coding of MCMC state representations and acceptance probability calculations tailored to a particular application. An alternative approach that we pursue in this paper is the use of a universal probabilistic modeling language (such as BLOG) and a generic Metropolis-Hastings-MCMC algorithm that supports custom offer distributions. Our algorithm gains flexibility by using MCMC states that are only incomplete descriptions of possible worlds, and we provide a general purpose for world partitions, such as MMC responses to specific questions, using MCMC for specific purposes.

sections.heading: 1 INTRODUCTION
sections.text: Many probable argumentation problems involve the reconstruction of (possibly related) real-world objects underlying some observed data: for example, the publications and authors mentioned in a series of bibliographic quotations, or the aircraft underlying a number of observed radar blips. As the number of possible ways to map a series of observations on underlying objects is enormous, these problems are extremely challenging for standard sampling. Specialized algorithms have been developed in the areas of recording connection [Fellegi and Sunter, 1969] and data association [Bar-Shalom and Fortmann, 1988], which provide approximate solutions for certain classes of models. Recently, Pasula et al. [2003] and Oh et al. [2004] have obtained state-of-the-art results on these problems using Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods. sections.text: These "possible worlds" are formally presented as model structures of a typed logical language of the first order. A typed language of the first order comprises a series of types, such as String, NaturalNum, Citation, and Publication, and a series of function symbols1, such as Name, Title, and PubCited. A model structure specifies a series of objects for each type, and for each function symbol specifies an assignment of argumentation stages to values. A BLOG model specifies a generative process for constructing such possible worlds. Fig. 1 shows a simplified version of the BLOG model that we use for quoting symbols. The model begins by explaining object types (line 1) and introducing some guaranteed objects that exist in all possible worlds. The rest of the model consists of two types of statements. Number statements appearing on lines 3 and 5 describe generative steps that predetermine new objects.

sections.heading: 4 MCMC STATES
sections.text: The obvious method of applying MCMC to a BLOG model is to let the MCMC states be possible worlds. However, the supply distribution of [Pasula et al., 2003] does not propose complete possible worlds. A complete possible world typically contains many publications that are not quoted, i.e., does not propose the value of PubCited (c) for any quote c. The world must state the values of the title and the NthAuthor for all existing publications. However, the supply distribution discussed in paragraph 2.1 never suggests titles or authors for unquoted publications. The conditional BN for the quotation comparison model makes it clear that attributes of unquoted publications are irrelevant: In a world where a publication p is not quoted, the titles and NthAuthor variables defined on p do not require active ancestors of queries or evidence variables.

sections.heading: 5 PERFORMING M-H STEPS EFFICIENTLY
sections.text: Our overarching goal is to calculate the probability ratio and update the MCMC state in time, which does not grow with the number of existing objects or the number of instantiated variables. This is not always possible, but application-specific implementations use different forms of structure to perform these calculations in constant time.

sections.heading: 5.1 DIFFERENCE DATA STRUCTURES
sections.text: We said in paragraph 3 that the M-H engine stores a copy of the current state sn before passing a modifiable copy to the applicant, but a complete copy of sn would take a linear time in terms of the number of variables instantiated, so our implementation does something more subtle. The state object passed to proposeNextState is actually a difference structure, or "patch," based on the current state sn. This difference structure contains a hash table that maps modified or newly instantiated basic variables to their new values, as well as a list of newly instantiated variables. In fact, the applicant only changes this patch; the underlying copy of sn remains unchanged. However, the difference structure supports all the same access methods as an ordinary MCMCState data structure: when a client asks for the value of a variable that has not been modified, the request of sn is simply passed on to the original state by the proposal of the initial state 1.
